oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Seneca Lake Survey Party
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Seneca Lake Survey Party members at work on the Cayuga-Seneca Canal, which joins Seneca Lake with the Erie Canal. New York State Engineer Carl F. Hopstein is at the far right, holding a meter stick.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Canals--New York (State); Canal construction workers; Cayuga-Seneca Canal (N.Y.); Seneca Lake--New York (State); Erie Canal (N.Y.)
Work & Labor; People
oai_dc:dc.dc:coverage: Seneca Lake - Seneca County - New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: silver gelatin developed-out paper print; b&w; 3 5/8 x 4 1/2 in. (7.62 x 10.16 cm.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Canal Boat Being Weighed at the Syracuse Weighlock Building
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Looking West on the Erie Canal, now Erie Boulevard. To the left of the Weighlock Building are warehouses with loading rigging, to the right is the Oswego Canal. A canal boat has been drawn into the lock, waiting for the lock gates to be closed and water drained out, so a tollmaster can weigh it on a cradle that is attached to a scale. Try it here at: http://eriecanalmuseum.org/wp/wp-content/themes/ecm/swf/ECMweb.swf
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Judd, M.E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Weighhouses; Canals--New York (State); Canal-boats--New York (State); Locks (Hydraulic engineering); Erie Canal (N.Y.)
Architecture; Transportation
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: silver gelatin photograph of an albumen stereoview created by M.E. Judd; b&w; 4 7/16 x 3 13/16 in. (11.27 x 9.68 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: The Museum is providing access to these materials for personal, educational and research purposes only. oai_dc:dc.dc:title: First Steel Canal Boat Company Barge, Passing Through Canastota, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: First trip of Cleveland Steel Canal Boat Company boats photographed passing through Canastota on their way to New York City. Visible in front is the steel-hulled steamer #5 Rockport, accompanied by five steel boats behind it. An older "laker" boat can be seen docked on the opposite side of the canal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Calton, Clarence P.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Canals--New York (State); Shipping--Great Lakes Region (North America); Barge-carrying ships
Transportation; Work & Labor

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Volunteer Life Saving Corps. of Syracuse, New York
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Staged photograph of the YMCA's Volunteer Lifesaving Corps. of Syracuse, New York. They have just pulled a fully-clothed man from an Erie Canal location in the city of Syracuse. The establishment of the United States Volunteer Lifesaving Corps. in 1890, and the style of the men's swimwear, suggests a date range of 1890-1900.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Canals--New York (State); United States. Life-Saving Service
People; Work & Labor
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: 4 9/16 x 3 5/8 (10.16 x 7.62 cm.) collodion printing-out paper mounted on 5 1/4 x 4 1/4 (12.7 x 10.16 cm.) paper board

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Competing Forms of Transportation: the Barge Canal, the New York Central Railroad, and an Automobile
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A view of a tugboat pulling barges on the Barge Canal contrasted with a New York Central Railroad train and a parked automobile. The 5-window coupe automobile model suggests the time period of 1935-1945, while the parallel alignment of the railroad and canal suggests a location between Buffalo and New York City.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Canals--New York (State); Barges; Automobiles
Transportation
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: silver gelatin developed-out paper print; b&w; 10 x 8 1/2 in. (7.62 x 10.16 cm.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Canal Boat George F. Weaver of Utica
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of a canal boat, the George F. Weaver, being pulled by a driver and a team of horses through the Black River Canal Lock. The man seated to the left on the boat is Henry Nestle, a lock tender.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: New York State Barge Canal Engineers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Group of New York State Canal engineers posed at a lock gate with surveying equipment. State engineer Carl F. Hopstein is standing second from the right. The construction period of the Barge Canal suggests a date range of 1905-1918 for this photograph.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: O'Brien & Hoolihan Surveyors Working on the Barge Canal
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: O'Brien & Hoolihan Contracting Company employees posed with surveying equipment at an unknown location. The steam shovel in the background suggests that this photograph was taken during construction of the Barge Canal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Andrew M. Barnes and Crew Trapped in Ice on Oneida Lake
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph print of the "Andrew M. Barnes" and another barge stuck in 18-20 inches deep of ice on Oneida Lake during the early winter of 1936. Stranded for a month, the crew were faced with a dwindling fuel and food supply.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: barges; gelatin silver prints; ice
Transportation; Work & Labor; Environment & Nature

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Building the Steamboat Iroquois in a Boatyard Near Onondaga Lake
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph print of the passenger steamboats "The Iroquois" and "The Mohawk" in mid-construction in a boatyard in Baldwinsville, N.Y. , ca. 1900. After a few years of service on Onondaga Lake, both boats were purchased in 1902 by Captain Brown of Syracuse, to serve as excursion boats for his Cayuga Lake Steamboat Company.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: unknown
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Transportation; Work & Labor

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Walter Bradley & Co. Working on the Barge Canal at Minetto, N.Y.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Laborers from Walter Bradley & Co.'s construction firm working on the Barge Canal in the Fulton, N.Y. area, ca. 1914. Even with dump trucks and steam shovels, some of the work still had to be finished by hand.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph of the interior of the Barge Canal Office at the Weighlock Building, Syracuse N.Y. State engineer Carl F. Hopstein is seated at the desk to the right. The Syracuse Weighlock building housed the Canal administrative offices until the 1950's.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Broadside for Red Bird Line
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Advertisement for packet boat passenger transport service. "Opposition to the Railroad" refers to the competition between packet boat lines and the Utica and Schenectady Railroad, which ran parallel to the Erie Canal route between the two cities. Railroads had become serious competitors to packet boat express lines by 1858.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Steam Press of Jewett, Thomas & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Advertisements
Transportation; Business & Industry

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Voucher for Payment on Contract for Construction of the DeRuyter Reservoir Feeder
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The DeRuyter Reservoir Feeder, also known as DeRuyter Lake, was created in 1860 to supply water to the Erie Canal. Jas. Wood was one of the contractors who constructed the Reservoir.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bond document, State of N.Y. Canal Department
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: State of N.Y. Canal Department Loan for the Enlargement of the Erie, the Oswego, the Cayuga, and Seneca Canals. A demand for increased freight transport prompted the enlargement of the Erie Canal between the years of 1836 and 1862, to 70 feet wide and 7 feet deep.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Voucher for payment for canal repairs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Payment from a Superintendent of Canal Repairs to John Hart for "bottoming out canal". The Erie Canal was drained every spring so laborers could remove debris that accumulated at the bottom of the canal.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Shipping receipt from Delahunt & Co
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Shipping receipt from Delahunt & Co. The reference to lighterage meant that the shippers were not allowed to pull goods on a barge tied behind their ship. Demurrage refers to the shippers being prompt in loading and unloading the freight, so the customer wouldn't be charged for more shipping services than necessary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Transportation; Business & Industry

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Broadside for Steamer Walter McMullin
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Originally owned and operated by Charles Strickland of Jordan, N.Y., the Walter McMullin continued to transport freight along the Erie Canal as late as 1917. The competition between canal express lines and the railroad is evident in this broadside.
